docs.title: Binary Ritual Encoding System (BRES)
docs.text: Welcome to the official documentation for the BRES framework. This site provides technical and interpretive insights into decoding symbolic ritual artifacts.

docs.title: BRES Technical Documentation
docs.text: BRES Technical Documentation

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Name: BRES Ritual Subtype Classifier Purpose: Automatically detect symbolic ritual encodings in undeciphered manuscripts or artifacts and classify them into culturally grounded ritual subtypes.

docs.title: Supported Ritual Subtypes
docs.text: Subtype Code Ritual Type Description RC Ritual Calendar Cyclical grammars using phase sequences (e.g., PTAN) with closure logic AR Astronomical Register Symbolic records of celestial cycles (e.g., Venus Table) IP Invocation Protocol Compact invocation clusters or symbolic spells CH Ceremonial Handbook Modular instructions or ritual guides with flexible order MC Mixed Calendar Hybrid astronomical and ritual-symbolic grammars

docs.title: Feature Extraction and Input Dimensions
docs.text:
The classifier uses the following core feature vectors per artifact:

Feature Description motif_density Percentage of sector-aligned ritual motifs (e.g., PTAN, AATAAN) closure_rate Presence and distribution of Neutral-phase closures symbolic_entropy Shannon entropy of phase transitions invocation_density Frequency of invocation-like sequences (e.g., A→T, A→A, A→P) alternation_rhythm Patterning of phase alternations (e.g., A→T→N cycles) calendar_fit_score Match to known calendrical formats (e.g., lunar, 36-day symbolic, Venus)

docs.title: Classification Algorithm
docs.text:
The classifier uses a decision-tree with rule-based thresholds derived from validated datasets:

  • If motif_density + closure_rate > 1.5 and entropy < 2.5 → classify as RC
  • If alternation_rhythm aligns with astronomical period → classify as AR
  • If invocation_density > 0.6 and sectors < 15 → classify as IP
  • If entropy > 3.5 and motif reuse is high → classify as CH
  • If multiple high scores across categories → classify as MC

docs.title: Classifier Output Example
docs.text:
{
  "type": "RC",
  "confidence": 0.93,
  "motif_match_score": 0.91,
  "calendar_alignment": "36-sector symbolic wheel",
  "closure_density": 0.23,
  "entropy": 2.1
}

docs.title: Classifier Validation
docs.text:
Artifacts used for classifier training and validation:

Artifact Source / Notes Subtype Phaistos Disc Phase-tested, PTAN motifs, closure logic, 36-sector ring RC Dresden Codex Venus Tbl Confirmed celestial period alignment AR Lead Plaque of Magliano Invocation-led cluster with strong closure boundary IP Book of Soyga (table 17) Entropic modularity, functional symbol recurrence CH Coligny Calendar Dual lunar/ritual hybrid logic with sectoral markers MC

docs.title: Developer Notes
docs.text:
• Source code for classification logic is in classifier.py
  • Dataset folder includes: sector_phase_streams/, motif_reference.json, entropy_scores.csv
  • To retrain or extend to a new ritual subtype, add sample artifacts to training/ and rerun subtype_classifier_train.py

docs.title: Deployment Guide
docs.text:
To publish this classifier as part of the GitHub Pages documentation:

  1. Ensure mkdocs.yml includes a new page:
  - Classification:
      - 'Ritual Subtypes': 'docs/subtypes.md'
  1. Place this markdown in docs/subtypes.md
  2. Commit changes:
git add docs/subtypes.md mkdocs.yml
git commit -m "Add ritual subtype classifier documentation"
git push origin main
mkdocs gh-deploy

For help replicating this classifier, see the Developer Guide.

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text: The BRES system is built on a modular architecture designed to support symbolic ritual classification across multiple domains.

docs.title: Core Modules
docs.text:
• Phase Assignment Engine: Converts glyphs to ritual phase tokens (P, T, A, N).
  • Motif Analyzer: Scans for repeated and statistically significant phase patterns.
  • Artifact Classifier: Determines whether an object is a Ritual Calendar, Astronomical Register, etc.
  • Script Generator: Builds interpretive ritual timelines or ceremonial scripts.

docs.title: Expansion Layers
docs.text:
• Cultural Ontology Map
  • Probabilistic Phase Support
  • Cross-artifact similarity scoring

Each module operates independently but integrates through a shared metadata pipeline.

docs.title: Classification Pipeline
docs.text:
A DecisionTreeClassifier (scikit-learn) assigns: - Primary Type: - A: Ritual Calendar - B: Invocation Litany - C: Astronomical Register - D: Divinatory Cosmogram

  • Subtype Cluster:
  • A1: Agricultural Calendar
  • A2: Sacrificial Wheel
  • C1: Venus Track (Dresden Codex)
  • C2: Eclipse Counter
  • etc.

docs.title: Training Data:
docs.text:
• Verified: Phaistos Disc, Venus Table (Dresden Codex)
  • Synthetic: 20 examples per type, using motif and entropy rules
  • All labeled with clear provenance (real vs. synthetic)

docs.title: Developer Implementation Guide – BRES (Binary Ritual Encoding System)
Overview
docs.text: This document describes how to implement the BRES system, including data ingestion, phase assignment, feature extraction, classification, and interpretive outputs. The goal is to help developers rebuild or extend BRES as a symbolic classifier and interpreter for ritual artifacts.

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
bres/
├── data/                  # Artifact glyph sequences (real + synthetic)
├── features/              # Feature extraction scripts
├── model/                 # Classifier training and subtype clustering
├── interpret/             # Ritual logic, segmentation, narratives
├── output/                # Markdown or PDF exports
└── interface/             # CLI or Web interface (optional)

docs.title: File: phase_map.py
docs.text:
• Maps each Glyph ID to a BRES Phase (A, T, P, N)
  • Supports:
  • Fixed map: id_to_phase = {1: 'A', 2: 'T', ...}
  • Probabilistic map: python phase_probs = { 1: {"A": 0.8, "T": 0.2}, 4: {"T": 0.9, "N": 0.1} }

docs.title: File: features/extract_bres_features.py
docs.text:
Main method:

def extract_bres_features(seq: str) -> dict:

Outputs: - Phase counts, transition matrix - Entropy (Shannon) - Motif frequencies (PTAN, ATAAN, etc.) - Spatial tags (if provided) - Used for both training and classification

docs.title: File: model/train_classifier.py
docs.text:
• Uses sklearn.tree.DecisionTreeClassifier: python clf = DecisionTreeClassifier(max_depth=4) clf.fit(X_train, y_train)
  • Outputs Type: A, B, C, D

docs.title: Subtype Clustering:
docs.text:
• KMeans clustering of normalized feature space
  • 2–3 subtypes per type (manual labeling)

docs.title: File: interpret/generate_narrative.py
docs.text: Steps after classification: 1. Segment phase stream by closure or motifs 2. Theme assignment by segment profile 3. Narrative generation using cultural ontology 4. Optional: Generate spiral/radial timeline charts

docs.title: File: features/spatial_tagging.py
docs.text:
• Tracks glyph index in:
  • Sector
  • Spiral or radial layout
  • Bins glyphs into bands (e.g., “Outer”, “Center”)
  • Used to analyze closure clustering or phase flow by depth

docs.title: Tools & Libraries
docs.text:
• pandas, numpy: Data processing
  • scikit-learn: Classifier + clustering
  • matplotlib: Visualization
  • markdown2, pdfkit (optional): Export formatting
  • streamlit or click: Web/CLI interface

docs.title: CLI/Web Integration
docs.text:
Optional front-end with:

$ bres analyze glyph_sequence.txt
$ bres interpret --artifact phaistos_disc
$ bres export --format pdf

Or use a Streamlit dashboard for upload + export + visualization.

docs.title: Artifact Input Formats
docs.text:
• Glyphs as ID stream: [1, 3, 5, 2, 4]
  • Sectored format (dict): {A1: [1,2], A2: [3,4,5], ...}
  • Optional: glyph spatial metadata (sector ID, spiral pos, glyph-in-sector)

docs.title: Rebuilding Workflow
docs.text:
1. Create glyph → phase mapping
  2. Load artifact (glyph list or sector map)
  3. Encode full phase stream
  4. Extract features
  5. Classify: Type + Subtype
  6. Interpret: Segment + Ritual Role
  7. Export results

This guide should enable any developer to rebuild the BRES pipeline or extend it into their own symbolic artifact decoding system.

docs.title: Feature Extraction
docs.text:
(Structural Metrics)

Each artifact’s phase sequence is processed into a feature vector via extract_bres_features_extended(). Features include: - Phase counts and proportions - Shannon entropy - Transition frequency matrix (e.g., A→T, T→P) - Key motif counts (e.g., PTAN, ATAAN) - Closure density - Spatial glyph metadata (for spiral or radial artifacts)

docs.title: Interpretation Pipeline
docs.text:
(Post-Classification)

Once classified, BRES proceeds to auto-interpret the artifact based on type:

docs.title: A – Ritual Calendar
docs.text:
• Segments by closure or motifs
  • Maps phase structure to ceremonial function
  • Outputs ritual season timeline + ceremonial script

docs.title: B – Invocation Litany
docs.text:
• Detects repetitive invocations
  • Builds call-and-response sequences

docs.title: C – Astronomical Register
docs.text:
• Aligns phases with planetary visibility or eclipses
  • Narrates ritual significance of celestial phenomena

docs.title: D – Divinatory Cosmogram
docs.text:
• Analyzes sector oppositions and closures
  • Interprets polarity structure and divinatory logic

docs.title: About the Author
docs.text:
My name is Amy Laird, and I am the developer of the Binary Ritual Encoding System (BRES) — a new methodological framework for decoding symbolic manuscripts through a lens of ritual sequence, phase logic, and calendrical alignment.

With a background spanning real estate operations, project management, and deep research into ancient manuscripts, I bring a hybrid of analytical precision and symbolic intuition. My ongoing work focuses on uncovering pattern-based systems embedded in undeciphered texts, beginning with the Voynich Manuscript, and now expanding into the Phaistos Disc, Dresden Codex, and other ancient symbolic artifacts.

docs.title: What is BRES?
docs.text:
BRES (Binary Ritual Encoding System) is a ritual sequence classification system based on a four-phase logic: - Passive (P) - Transitional (T) - Active (A) - Neutral (N)

These phases form the grammar of symbolic ritual sequences, allowing researchers to identify closure loops, transitional gates, and active invocations within undeciphered glyph-based texts. The BRES framework does not assume a linguistic cipher; rather, it interprets sequences as ceremonial instructions or encoded calendars.

docs.title: Why This Project?
docs.text:
There has long been a gap in symbolic manuscript research: most interpretations assume either language-based encipherment or pure decoration. The BRES hypothesis proposes that many ancient artifacts encode ritual logic — not language, but a ritual calendar or process model.

This project seeks to:

  • Prove that recurring glyph sequences match symbolic ritual structures.
  • Classify sectors by their ritual function using BRES logic.
  • Reveal calendrical structure in encoded artifacts.
  • Develop a toolkit for applying this framework to other undeciphered texts.

docs.title: My Hypothesis
docs.text:
The central hypothesis is this:

The Phaistos Disc, like the Voynich Manuscript and parts of the Dresden Codex, encodes a calendrical-ritual structure based on symbolic function, using repeated glyph sequences arranged in four-phase cycles of Passive, Transitional, Active, and Neutral operations.

This method, if confirmed across multiple artifacts, may redefine how we interpret ancient symbolic systems. It suggests these objects were not meant to be read as texts, but to be enacted — as ritual calendars, ceremonial guides, or cosmological timers.

docs.title: Current Focus
docs.text:
This documentation presents: - A full BRES classification of the Phaistos Disc. - A database of glyphs, sectors, and interpretations. - Technical components for the classifier, feature extractor, and use-case applications. - An expandable foundation for analyzing additional artifacts.

Welcome to the Binary Ritual Encoding System. This is only the beginning.

docs.title: BRES Phase Grammar
docs.text: Phase Symbol Ritual Function Passive P Grounding, purification, fertility Transitional T Threshold crossing, transformation Active A Invocation, offering, sacrifice Neutral N Closure, silence, sealing

docs.title: Glyph-to-Phase Assignment
docs.text: Assignments are based on: - Iconographic and mythological parallels - Phase motif clustering - Cross-cultural ritual role alignment

docs.title: Probabilistic Assignments:
docs.text: Glyphs may map to multiple phases with confidence levels (e.g., 01 → A: 0.8, T: 0.2). These are used for smoother, more nuanced classification.

docs.title: Ritual Subtype Detection Classifier Module
docs.text: This module enhances the Binary Ritual Encoding System (BRES) by introducing an integrated classifier capable of distinguishing between ritual subtypes across symbolic manuscripts. The classifier evaluates symbolic phase sequences and structural motifs to categorize artifacts into known ritual formats, including calendars, invocation sequences, astronomical registers, and others.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
To move beyond phase decoding alone and offer automated classification of an artifact's function based on encoded symbolic structure. This enables:

  • Faster identification of document type (e.g., calendar, ritual script, astronomical register)
  • Subtype differentiation (e.g., solar vs. lunar calendars)
  • Consistent labeling of new or uncertain manuscripts

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
• Input: A tokenized phase stream (e.g., ['P', 'T', 'A', 'A', 'N', ...])
  • Features Extracted:
  • Motif frequency distribution (e.g., PTAN, AATAA, etc.)
  • Closure pattern entropy
  • Invocation clustering density
  • Alternation signatures (e.g., A↔T transitions)
  • Total sequence length and boundary markers
  • Model: Decision-tree backed symbolic classifier with Bayesian reinforcement
  • Output: Predicted ritual subtype with confidence score (e.g., "ritual calendar", 0.94)

docs.title: Subtypes Detected
docs.text: Subtype Key Indicators Ritual Calendar Regular closures, monthly cycles, PTAN motifs Invocation Script High invocation density, repeated A-pairings Astronomical Register Phase drift, irregular closure, planetary sync Ceremonial Path Text Linear sequence with gateway motifs (P→T→A→N) Hybrid / Uncertain Mixed or ambiguous patterns

docs.title: Training and Validation
docs.text:
• Sample Data: BRES-decoded sequences from:
  • Phaistos Disc
  • Coligny Calendar
  • Lead Plaque of Magliano
  • Dresden Venus Table
  • Synthetic Data: 200+ modeled ritual sequences for robust training
  • Validation:
  • Holdout cross-validation
  • Symbolic alignment scoring
  • Permutation tests (e.g., p < 0.01 for subtype clustering accuracy)

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
{
  "artifact": "Phaistos Disc",
  "classification": "ritual calendar",
  "confidence": 0.91,
  "features": {
    "PTAN motifs": 5,
    "closures": 12,
    "invocation density": 0.32,
    "entropy": 0.72
  }
}

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
1. Input a BRES-decoded phase sequence into the classifier.
  2. The classifier analyzes structural and symbolic patterns.
  3. It returns a ritual subtype and scores.

This enables researchers to treat undecoded artifacts more systematically and link them to known ceremonial archetypes.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Extend classifier with multilingual OCR phase mapping
  • Integrate with GitHub-hosted BRES Toolkit CLI/Web version
  • Add export tools (CSV/JSON) for batch artifact classification

docs.title: Binary Ritual Encoding System (BRES) – Expanded Technical Documentation (2025)
Overview
docs.text: The Binary Ritual Encoding System (BRES) is a symbolic classification and interpretation framework for decoding ritual logic embedded in ancient, non-linguistic artifacts such as the Phaistos Disc and the Dresden Codex. BRES identifies modular glyph sequences using a four-phase grammar—Passive, Transitional, Active, Neutral (P, T, A, N)—and classifies them as one of several ritual types. It now includes subtype analysis and a full interpretive ritual generation pipeline.

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text: This section outlines real-world and research applications of the Binary Ritual Encoding System (BRES) applied to the Phaistos Disc.

docs.title: 🔮 Ritual Structure Interpretation
docs.text: Analyze sector sequences to infer ceremonial patterns, symbolic hierarchies, or encoded myth cycles.

docs.title: 🧬 Symbolic Data Encoding
docs.text: Use BRES to reverse-engineer glyph design as an intentional data storage mechanism grounded in ritual logic.

docs.title: 🗺️ Cultural Comparative Analysis
docs.text: Compare BRES phase templates to: - Egyptian decanal calendars - Mayan Venus tables - Coligny calendar from Gaul - Etruscan or Greek ritual schema

docs.title: 🔁 Classifier Testing
docs.text: Train and test automated classification systems against encoded phase sequences to simulate ancient ritual logic.

docs.title: 📊 Educational Tools
docs.text: Use this system to teach symbolic pattern recognition, ritual semiotics, and cross-cultural encoding techniques.

docs.title: Workflow Examples
docs.text: These examples illustrate how to decode and analyze Phaistos Disc sectors using the Binary Ritual Encoding System (BRES).

docs.title: Sector A5
docs.text:
• Glyphs: 2 (Shield), 12 (Man Walking), 4 (Captive), 40 (Ox Back), 33 (Duck/Goose)
  • Phase Sequence: N,A,T,T,P

docs.title: Analysis:
docs.text:
• N (Shield): Ritual begins with a closure or boundary marker.
  • A (Man Walking): Action or invocation enters.
  • T (Captive, Ox Back): Transitional phase invoking restraint and strength.
  • P (Goose): Culminates in a fertility offering.

This structure aligns with ceremonial combat or sacrificial rites leading to renewal.

docs.title: Sectors A14 and A20
docs.text:
• Common Phase Template: N,T,T,A,A,P
  • Ritual Roles:
  • T (Hide, Ship): Preparation and journey
  • A (Arrow, Chisel): Enactment and creation
  • P (Flower): Renewal

docs.title: Inference:
docs.text: Multiple sectors encode a journey-action-renewal structure, indicating shared ritual function across phases.

docs.title: Sector A1
docs.text: • Phase Sequence: N,A,A,A,P

docs.title: Key Features:
docs.text:
• Starts with N (Shield), ends in P (Flower)
  • Strong invocation cluster (3x A)

Represents an open invocation sequence concluding in renewal—ideal template for a petition-based ritual.

docs.title: 📐 Suggested Workflow for Researchers
docs.text:
1. Select Sector: Choose a sector from the full classification.
  2. Extract Phase Sequence: Read and decode BRES sequence (e.g. T,P,A,N)
  3. Interpret Transition Logic: Map each phase to symbolic ritual function.
  4. Compare Across Sectors: Identify recurring templates or divergences.
  5. Document Inference: Align with cultural parallels and hypothesize purpose.

Use this method to build comparative ritual maps and decode ceremonial narratives.
